jolt.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to move suddenly and roughly, or to make someone or something move in this way
jolt.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: We jolted along rough wet roads through an endless banana plantation.
jolt.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to give someone a sudden shock or surprise
jolt.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: It jolted me into making the decision to quit.
Her sharp words seemed to jolt him out of his depression.
jolt.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: The oil crisis has given the government quite a jolt.
Melanie experienced a jolt of surprise.
Henry sat up with a jolt.
jolt.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: People felt the first jolt of the earthquake at about 8 am.
jolt.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a shock that causes prices and markets to change suddenly
jolt.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Many companies got a jolt from the attempted coup.
The crisis gave a jolt to the world energy markets.
jolt.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to give a sudden shock to a person, company, or market
jolt.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Traders were jolted yesterday by reports warning of recession.
The eruption of war in the Middle East jolted the worldâ€™s financial markets.
